body:
Bill - it would be good to track this issue so that we don't drop it on the floor.

> On Aug 5, 2016, at 1:19 PM, Bill Graham notifications@github.com wrote:
> 
> @ashvina good observation. I'd love to remove then and that was my initial intent, but the executor needs that info and is written in python. Serializing it means we don't need to change the executor code, so I kept in there for now. Without it we'd need to reimplement that logic in python to reconstruct. I don't love having the logic implemented in two places, but I agree we might want to do that instead before we ship scaling, but in a later patch.

@objmagic  - per our conversation this afternoon, I added an additional test case for configuring  the equivalent of 
`heron submit local --verbose  ~/.heron/examples/heron-examples.jar  com.twitter.heron.examples.ExclamationTopology ExclamationTopology`

in heronrc.test as:

```
heron:submit:local --verbose  --topology-file-name ~/.heron/examples/heron-examples.jar  --topology-class-name com.twitter.heron.examples.ExclamationTopology --topology-name ExclamationTopology
```

also added a baseline test and a comparison test :
test_parser_commandline_norc  (using python's default argparse)
test_parser_commandline_positional_withrc (using argparser )

Please let me know if this meets your expecations. also added some house keeping code for testability in HeronArgumentParser

Still this does not work at all.
Here is my `.heronrc`:

```
heron:submit:local --verbose  --topology-file-name ~/.heron/examples/heron-examples.jar  --topology-class-name com.twitter.heron.examples.ExclamationTopology --topology-name ExclamationTopology
```

Neither `heron submit local` nor `heron submit` works for me.
@objmagic - can you please comment why this is needed?

it is possible that user simply imports the `Log` object without calling function `configure`. This may cause exception "No handler found". So we at top level add a `logging.basic_config()` to prepare a default handler so that `Log` will always be properly initialized.
please add this comment in the code.
üëç
üëç If @objmagic is good with this, let us merge this.
@taishi8117 - can you please take care of @objmagic feedback and we should be good to merge it.
üëç As @ashvina mentioned, please create the SSL issue - which we can resolve later.
@windie - this should go into heron/storm - since this is storm api 1.0.0 compatible. Heron api under heron/api - is not supposed to be used by the users - since it is a hidden API.

@objmagic - that is not the intended use of heronrc. it used only for optional parameters. In your example, topology file name, topology class are positional arguments or rather required arguments. For example, the following is a valid .heronrc file

`heron:submit:local --verbose`

When you submit a command

```
heron submit local ~/.heron/examples/heron-examples.jarcom.twitter.heron.examples.ExclamationTopology ExclamationTopology 
```

automatically verbose option is enabled. In order words, verbose option is enabled for all the topologies being submitted to local cluster.

@kramasamy They should have been fixed in https://github.com/twitter/heron/pull/1197/commits/4ab7e4f586e05cb8925e7c9cd2f00d8b005df11c and https://github.com/twitter/heron/pull/1197/commits/e0ecb77124984d9f5c908c8536a574c7c31a75f2.

I made some small changes on website. Can we hold this PR for a little while?
If you pass `--verbose` flag on command line, logging level is set to `logging.DBEUG`, otherwise it is `logging.INFO`.
or do you mean you want more granularity? like command-line argument `--verbose=LEVEL`?
@lucperkins I just merged in #1226. Can you build the website again?
@objmagic That most recent commit is a new build that takes your changes into account.

There is actually a heron version string that is passed in whose purpose was to be the version that the release was tagged with. What are peoples thoughts about

either
- removing that and allowing the override as I have implemented here

or
- removing the git parsing for the version string

(See: https://github.com/twitter/heron/pull/1227/files#diff-489b3a1dc33fb4234394f371a8e67fe1R104)

It appears that `HERON_VERSION` is only used in naming the file which feels a bit misleading.

@lucperkins - sure. let us know once you are done.

Nice catch. Thanks for the contribution. Could you sign the CLA first?
https://engineering.twitter.com/opensource/cla
Signed.

Just wanted to add a bit of a note here. This change caused a pretty significant performance degradation (30% or so) in our topologies. The reason is kind of interesting.

In our case we are using kafka which uses log4j directly. `log4j-over-slf4j` replaces all of the `log4j` methods and routes them through `slf4j` so that they can be dispatched to another logger. When this dependency was removed it caused that to no longer be the case. Heron was setting the log level to `INFO` for `slf4j` which also ended up setting the `log4j` level to `INFO` as well. When the dependency was removed this was no longer the case because the two logging mechanisms were separated. `log4j` defaults to a log level of DEBUG which meant that kafka (and other dependencies in a worse way for some other topologies) started to output all of their debug log to essentially /dev/null because it is the default for `log4j`. So we could not see the increase in log messages in our heron logs and had to profile the topology when it was in a bad state vs a good state to see that kafka was spending a tremendous amount of time logging out debug messages.

I think we should consider adding this dependency back in to align all of the logging to the same place, otherwise we could have multiple loggers writing to different places on different log levels which can be very confusing and is not apparent without some pretty serious digging.

The message that you put in the description of this issue happens in our topologies as well but does not have any impact on the runtime of the topology. My feeling is a simple log message about multiple bindings is far better than accidentally turning on debug mode for any dependency that uses `log4j` explicitly.

Hi @ajorgensen Thanks for the details

The issue reported is not a ignorable log message. Topology deployment on YARN cluster fails if both `slf4j-log4j` binding and `log4j-over-slf4j` are present. The applications quits to avoid infinite loop, search for `preempting StackOverflowError` in the description. 

Is it feasible to add log4j configuration instead of adding a dependency?

It is but this will mean anyone using Kafka or anytl dependency  that uses
log4j directly will need to either add the log4j-over-slf4j dependency or
have a log4j.propeties file. My issue there is that failure case is not at
all apaarent and very hard to find whereas the error you saw was very clear
and easy to fix. The only way I found this was by asking why the
performance of my topology degraded enough times to finally uncover the
issue. The lack of visibility here I think is reason enough to revert this
change and if there's a conflict you can add an explicit exclude. If
someone has a better way of handling this I'd love to hear it.

This is because by default we are trying to supply java utility logging (j.u.l) for slf4j.

@nlu90 is looking at the duplicated logging dependencies which is required by Twitter internally while not needed for open source. We are thinking to remove unneeded dependencies.

I don't think it is related to heron.api; could u share the log-files in your sandbox?

BTW,  heron.api is not encouraged to use for now since it is not stable and would be changed quite a bit in near future.

Ok, I will keep using backtype.storm, but is there performance different between backtype and heron.api.

Besides, which specific file you want to take a look at?

Thanks for your reply.

Since JDK14 is too old to be compatible with logback I use. But do you think it is a good to remove slf4j-jdk14-1.7.7.jar from the /usr/local/heron/lib/third_party folder.

Would the remove cause any issue in actual running?

There is no performance difference between backtype and heron.api.

I want the logs mentioned in here: http://twitter.github.io/heron/docs/getting-started-troubleshooting/
~/.herondata/topologies/{cluster}/{role}/{TopologyName}/heron-executor.stdout
~/.herondata/topologies/{cluster}/{role}/{TopologyName}/log-files/
@nlu90 could have better ideas on this.
@xcf1992 - the com.twitter.heron.api is an internal API and you are discouraged to use it. You should use either backtype.storm.\* or org.apache.storm.\*

I think we need either one or the other, `log4j-over-slf4j` delegates all log4j calls to slf4j so when we set the log level it gets applied to both. `slf4j-log4j12` delegates all slf4j calls to log4j so we would have to set the log level in log4j land (I believe) and add log4j as a dependency. Given that we've already chosen the former route with how we set the log level and use `slf4j` I think we necessarily need to use `log4j-over-slf4j` in order to get a unified logging experience that is consistent and work around cases where another dependency has chosen to go the other way.

I think this these files files may be the most important:

[heron-executor.stdout.txt](https://github.com/twitter/heron/files/412318/heron-executor.stdout.txt)

[container_1_g_6.log.0.txt](https://github.com/twitter/heron/files/412321/container_1_g_6.log.0.txt)
[heron-stmgr-stmgr-1.log.INFO.20160810-160954.14282.txt](https://github.com/twitter/heron/files/412327/heron-stmgr-stmgr-1.log.INFO.20160810-160954.14282.txt)

Cause I have to remove any info about the service or company, let me know if any other file may also neededed.

Thanks

Two doubts:
1. What if the users of log4j provides a properties file and uses custom appenders? They will need to debug why appenders are not working and reconfigure log properties. Sometimes it is not feasible.
2. The default log4j appender is `ConsoleAppender`. I thought all console writes are redirected to .out files? Then the logs should not got unnoticed.

If at all this is inevitable, do you think `shading` this dependency will work?
@maosongfu what do you think about this issue?

Correct. However the heron UI provides links directly into the log files which means it is required that the logs go through heron in order to be written into the correct place. Going through log4j will result in logs not being accessible from the heron ui so the end user would have a worse experience and would have to find the logs manually each time. In order for that all to work heron necessarily needs to handle all of the logging to make sure its accessible.

I believe the default log4j logger actually logs to stdout but because we were using slf4j to handle the logging it was never actually getting to a place where I could see it.
Ping.
@objmagic - is this ready to be merged?

Yes. But I'm sorry that unit tests are hard to write and I'm not in good health condition now. I may add some later. Integration test which Taishi now is writing could be helpful though.

Anyway, I'd say we can merge this PR.

> On Aug 11, 2016, at 00:30, Karthik Ramasamy notifications@github.com wrote:
> 
> @objmagic - is this ready to be merged?
> 
> ‚Äî
> You are receiving this because you were mentioned.
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub, or mute the thread.
Ok - sounds good. I will merge it tomorrow.
@maosongfu - can you please take a look at this?

The `log4j-over-slf4j` bridge is a topology dependency. Dependencies for some use cases should not become platform dependencies. Classpath management becomes hard when Heron dependencies are integrated with runtime dependencies. In such cases "hard-coding" topology dependencies would add to the challenge. 

Moreover there are many deployment specific logging integrations. Would'nt it be better if log4j bridge be a configurable runtime dependency instead of packaging it with Heron? I.e. allow users to easily remove this bridge at runtime.

Heron is the runtime. I don't agree with you the `log4j-over-slf4j` is a topology dependency. You are running topology code inside the heron runtime it should be heron's responsibility to configure how that logging works. I also do not agree that it would be better if log4j should be configured separately, it would potentially break the linking between the heron logs and the ui in a way that is not immediately apparent.

Additionally the failure case for not including `log4j-over-slf4j` is _much_ worse than the failure case for including it. If any dependency uses log4j directly it will silently start spewing DEBUG logging information which depending on the dependency can cause serious performance degradations in the topology without any indication as to why. In order to figure out what was causing the problem I had to profile the app and go through the call tree to see that kafka was spending a lot of time writing debug information.

I think that if you are running your code inside someone else's runtime (Hadoop, Heron, Storm, etc) that it is their responsibility to configure the logging system to do the right thing.

`slf4j` is supposed to be a facade that allows you to write code against a common interface and then the place where you are running the code can configure how that information gets logged out. The runtime decides what logging system it wants to use and configures it accordingly, if you only include `slf4j-api` or use `log4j` directly this just works its when dependencies start including `log4j-over-slf4j` or `slf4j-log4j12` directly and configuring logging that this breaks down because the runtime is suddenly not able to make the decisions it needs to to work.

According to the container_1_g_6.log.0, it is a known issue:

```
[2016-08-10 16:10:01 -0700] com.twitter.heron.instance.HeronInstance SEVERE:  Exception caught in thread: SlaveThread with id: 13 
java.lang.NoClassDefFoundError: com/esotericsoftware/reflectasm/ConstructorAccess

    at com.twitter.heron.api.serializer.KryoSerializer.deserialize(KryoSerializer.java:49)
```

which is reported by @ajorgensen in https://github.com/twitter/heron/issues/1165. And it is fixed in latest master branch and release 0.14.2.
@xcf1992 Can u give it a try on 0.14.2? Thanks.

:+1: Thanks for this contribution
I tested the classpath on local yarn cluster by adding YARN jars and config xml files. It worked as expected. There is no need to copy jars anymore. I also tested with by adding `heron:submit:* --extra-launch-classpath <value>` to .heronrc
Thanks a lot. I will try 0.14.2 to see if this get fixed.
This PR will be refined after integration test PR.

üëç  @objmagic - can you check this as well?

For posterity and to summarize a conversation in chat, the path forward here is to provide the logging bridge as a runtime dependency on the classpath rather than keeping it as a compile time dependency. This will allow people to point to a different logging bridge if they need to depending on their use case. I can look into making this change or someone else would be more than welcome to. I'll open up another issue to track it and we can close this issue.
Integration test's top level dir should be renamed to `integration_test`, instead of `integration-test`, because python doesn't like `-`. I will do it once other related PRs are all merged.
Will remove pyheron dir, as it's unnecessary
